channel.title: C++ question, mkay
channel.description:
So, I'm trying to create my own SCAR-like IDE, for a little language, (NQC, if you are interested), and I've come to a little dead-end. You guys know how in SCAR, when you start typing the name of a function, there is a little tooltip that shows the function type, name, etc? I was wondering how to make a tooltip like that, and how to parse the code for custom functions to add to that list (as in, a simple lexer). Can somebody help me?
Thanks in advance, ~io9`
EDIT: I have an idea how to do the lexer, (just copy the line that declares the function, and strip all new lines and extra spaces) EDIT 2: Also, do you know if any code-editing control (such as Scintilla) allows for creating such tooltips?

item.title: C++ question, mkay
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

Parsing is not necessarily an easy task, especially, if the language happens to be context-dependant. IDEs that support somewhat advanced “intellisense” usually first obtain an Abstract Syntax Tree of the code, and use it for their code information, code completion, and other features. For some languages, the compiler itself can generate such an AST (or similar), or there are tools available that do so (Usually, to XML format). If that’s not the case, and the language is somewhat hard to parse, you might want to use one of the many free tools / libraries available, such as ANTLR, LEX, YACC or boost::spirit.
(Note: For C++, and for parsing a not too complex language, easiest one to use is probably boost::spirit).
(Note2: Depending on the language and on the features you require, it might not be necessary to parse the whole code, or not necessary to generate an AST at all).

item.title: C++ question, mkay
item.dc:creator: @bakatool bakatool
item.description:
@bakatool wrote:

it’s called auto dropdown window

you can make it using a API called SendMessage

const int CB_SHOWDROPDOWN = 0x14F; //hex value to drop down combobox
bool bShowDropdown = true; //show it or not. well just make sure its 1.
SendMessage HWND_OF_EDIT, CB_SHOWDROPDOWN, bShowDropdown, 0

docs.microsoft.com

CB_SHOWDROPDOWN message - Windows applications

An application sends a CB\_SHOWDROPDOWN message to show or hide the list box of a combo box that has the CBS\_DROPDOWN or CBS\_DROPDOWNLIST style.
